en.value: Describing the place where you live - Prepositions of place "in, at, near" etc.
In this lesson we’ll learn how to talk about where we live. We’ll look at ways of saying whether our town is big or small, or busy or quiet. Have a look at the words below.
Read and listen to the words.
Select the answer to the question.
Where do you live? [k]I live in London.[/k]
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
They live in a small town in Spain.
We use the term "hometown" to talk about the town in which we grew up.
My hometown is Reading. It's near London.
We use the word "hometown" to talk about the place in which we grew up.
He lives in a town near Paris.
I come from a big town.
Select the word that you hear.

We have three different words to describe settlements: "village", "town" and "city". There are lots of funny criteria that make a "town" a "town" and a "city" a "city", and so on, but all you really need to know is that a village is smaller than a town, and a town is smaller than a city!
Select the smallest type of settlement from the sentences below.
New York is a busy city.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Two holiday-goers are talking about where they live.
I'm from a small town near Boston. And you?
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
I'm from a town near Paris.
Put the settlements in order from smallest to largest.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Fill in the gap using the image.
Where do you live? Write or record your response.
I live in a small town near Buenos Aires. It is very quiet.
When we want to talk about where something / someone is located, we can use prepositions of place. We’re going to learn a few basic ones in this unit. Have a look at some examples below.
My hometown is not far from London.
We normally use "in" with towns, cities and countries.
He lives in a town near Paris.
We use "in" with towns, cities and countries.
Is your hotel far from the centre?
My office is next to St Pancras station.
Select the preposition you hear in the audio.
We are at the bus stop.
We use "at" with a specific or exact location.
We use "at" with countries and cities.
We use "at" to talk about an exact location.
Match the beginning and end of each sentence.
Select the three prepositions of place in the following sentences.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
My office is [k]next to[/k] St Pancras station.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
She comes [k]from[/k] Bordeaux, a city [k]in[/k] France.
My hotel is [k]n[/k][k]e[/k][k]x[/k][k]t[/k] to the central station.
Select the preposition of place we use with specific locations.
Match the answer to the question.
My office is near the station.
We are at the bus stop.
Let's have another look at all the prepositions of place we've learned:
She lives [k]in[/k] a small village in Spain.
My hotel is not [k]far[/k] from Chinatown.
Type the preposition of place you think fits best.
Marco comes from Italy. He lives [k]in|near|not far from[/k] Venice.
